Award.AwardTitle: 2016 Writing Workshop for Junior Researchers in Statistical Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the participation of junior researchers in a workshop held at the Joint Statistical Meetings in Chicago, Illinois in July and August 2016. The workshop focuses on effective technical writing for new researchers in the statistical sciences, who seek to publish their research or to present their research plans in the form of grant proposals for federal funding. Researchers, especially new researchers, often have difficulty disseminating their research results not because of the quality of the research but rather because of inappropriate choices of publication venues for the particular research and/or because of poor presentation of technical material to the chosen audience. The National Institute of Statistical Sciences and the American Statistical Association will manage the Workshop.

This workshop will open with tutorial sessions on the organization of material for a technical article or grant application, on technical writing techniques, and on the specific missions and audiences of key journals in the statistical sciences. Following the introductory tutorial, each participating new researcher will work individually with an experienced journal editor as mentor to address these issues on an individualized basis in a draft of the new researcher's work. Revisions following this guidance will be critiqued by the mentor to assure that the new researcher's implementation of writing techniques has been successful before the article or the grant proposal is submitted for review. More information about this activity can be found at http://www.amstat.org/meetings/wwjr/index.cfm?fuseaction=main. This award is jointly supported by the Infrastructure and Statistics programs in the NSF Division of Mathematical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Progress in science depends on the continuing communication among researchers that is accurate, detailed, unambiguous and clear.  This is essential for published research can be completely understood, evaluated and even replicated by others based on the technical publication.  Thus, excellent technical writing is a specific skill that researchers need to acquire early in their careers.  The requirements for technical accuracy, concise expression, and precision in detailed explanations make technical writing challenging. So, writing for a technical context is quite different from other forms of writing with respect to the writing process, the format and the style. Further, writing for a mathematical science is differnt from writing for other sciences or social sciences.  This workshop brought junior researchers within five years of PhD together with senior researchers and journal editors who provided instruction in how to write technical journal articles and grant proposals in the mathematical and statistical sciences.  The workshop opened with a tutorial that first addressed the writing process and then considered the technical aspects of writing for statistical, biostatistical and mathematical audiences. Presentations followed on related topics including journal selection, the publication process from submission through reviewing and revision, and ethical issues encountered in research publication.  A separate session addressed special linguistic issues non-native English speakers encounter in drafting manuscripts. A unique and valuable feature of this workshop was the individual mentoring.  Each participant was matched with a senior researcher or journal editor based on the technical area of the draft manuscript that the participant had submitted in advance. Following the general session, the mentor and the participant worked together the particular aspects of writing the participant most needed to improve.
